taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [For C. F. Lessing, 1809–1862, German-born botanist, his nephew K. F. Lessing, and grandfather G. E. Lessing]

bio:treatment.discussion: In gland-bearing lessingias, the glands may be stipitate and/or sessile (gland-dotted, sometimes in pits) and may be found on stems, leaves, and/or phyllaries. They are seldom restricted to the faces of leaves or phyllaries and are usually most prominent on leaf and/or phyllary margins.

key_statement.description: Corollas yellow (sometimes pink or suffused with purple in peripheral florets of L. tenuis ).

Style-branch appendages truncate-penicillate, 0.1–0.4 mm, corolla tubes with brown-purple band inside.
Plants eglandular or phyllaries sparsely gland-dotted (San Francisco peninsula, California)
Plants ± glandular.

Phyllaries usually glabrous, rarely villous, sometimes stipitate-glandular or gland-dotted.
Basal leaves usually persistent at flowering; cauline leaves stipitate-glandular; involucres hemispheric to campanulate; corollas lavender (never white)
Basal leaves usually withering by flowering; cauline leaves sometimes stipitate-glandular; involucres cylindric to broadly obconic; corollas white (occasionally pale lavender).
Cauline leaves gland-dotted (in pits) and sometimes stipitate-glandular; style-branch appendages usually lanceolate, sometimes truncate-penicillate

Phyllaries villous to tomentose or woolly, sometimes gland-dotted as well.

Stems erect; apices of phyllaries green or purple; inner phyllaries scarious; pappi white to tan.
Cauline leaves eglandular.
Basal leaves withering by flowering; involucres 4–8 mm; style-branch appendages truncate-penicillate; pappi usually shorter than cypselae (except in Sonoma County, California)
Basal leaves persistent at flowering; involucres (5–)8–13 mm; style-branch appendages lanceolate; pappi equaling or longer than cypselae
Cauline leaves gland-dotted (in pits, rarely stipitate-glandular in L. virgata , glands sometimes obscured by tomentum).
Cauline leaf faces glabrous or villous to tomentose; heads usually at ends of branchlets; florets 6–25; corollas lavender (never white)
Cauline leaf faces villous to woolly; heads usually in axils of leaves; florets 3–6; corollas usually white, sometimes pale lavender
